body: If so, won't it be better to create it using heap_ associated with ex_globals. If there is a connection info that can be shared across context or ESP fragments, separate them out and store it in cli_globals, Pass that info to ExLobGlobals in ex_globals.  It is strange to see the ExLobGlobals being constructed from system heap.  And I couldn't find where is it being deleted?  There is a possibility of memory leak.

The ExLobGlobals is deleted in  ExpLOBinterfaceCleanup. Will look at getting rid of system new.  There was some issue with using the Map template class with an internal heap. The lobPtrs are stored as a standard template class within the ExLobGlobals.
+1, with this merged, I think I can make new release 2.2 package and start a new vote to release R2.2.

Thanks @mashengchen.  I understand that if the  method RetryCounter::shouldRetryInnerMinutes() returns false, the mxosrvr won't be restarted;, If it returns true the mxosrvr would be started.

In this method, the peek would get the head of the entry rather than the last entry. For the 2nd case (say 5 times in 25 mins and 6th time after many hours), shouldn't we look at the last entry via peekLast().  offer() would add at the last

thanks Dave, it is yet another typo, Already fixed. 
It saves me another mistake.

@selvaganesang 
No, the design is that it always compares the first time against the last time, here in your case , that will be a many hours+25mins interval, we consider the sixth time is an accident down, not a man-made, because there is a long interval. so there will restart the dcs server.

The failure of jenkins is caused by jdbc test for catalog api.
I have modify the test case.

I have tested it with sqlci and it returned like below:
>>prepare dd from insert into chtest values(9,?); 

--- SQL command prepared.
>>execute dd using '123456789012345678901234567890123456789087866';

** WARNING[8402] A string overflow occurred during the evaluation of a character expression. **

The string could be insert into the database but will be cutoff by the max chars the column could store, it  
is right to do so. But when using T4 (trafci) to insert the string , it could be insert into database as long as it's numbers of bytes less than the column length, like this

C_ID        C_CHAR                                                                                                                  
----------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
          1 1234567890123456789012345678                                                                                            
          6 123456789012345678901234567890                                                                                          
          8 +                                                                                
          9 123456789012345678901234567890                                                                                          
         12 123456789012345678901234567890123456789087866

The fifth row(id is 12), is inserted by trafci,  chars numbers of it obviously  larger than 30, while the fourth row(id is 9) is inserted by sqlci, and the query is  "execute dd using'123456789012345678901234567\
890123456789087866';" , same as the fifth row, but the string is inserted correctly(?It should not be correct)!  This is really strange behavior of executor, right?

I think this behavior of sql should be checked carefully, and my commit could avoid it in the  driver  level .  @DaveBirdsall

I overlooked the fact you are sending the difference between the current time stamp and the first. This change looks ok for most cases.  With the current defaults, there might be always a case where the strategy didn't start the  mxosrvr, but you would want it to be started. Consider a case where there were 5 failures within a minute, but 6th failure after 20 minutes.  I think this woudn't start the mxosrvr based on current defaults. This may not be considered as a vicious failure  as you have said, while six failures in a minute could be considered as a vicious.  Hopefully, we can tickle the DCS server some way externally to start the mxosrvr in such a case instead of waiting for 30 more minutes.
I am a little confused about this , although select *from udf(event_log_reader()) limit 1; seems not have problem , so close it first.
agree , it's will have several situation from your suggestion, i need to think about it.

To see more errors with sprintf,/printf you might want to compile with -Wformat -Werror compiler flags.  However -Werror would make all the warnings to be treated as errors and hence more changes to be done.
I agree with @DaveBirdsall. This should be handled at the executor layer
All changes look good to me. Thank you.

My suggestion would be to change the defaults. If there are N failures in 5 minutes, stop restarting the mxosrvr for 30 minutes. If the current failure is more than X minutes away from the last failure, restart the mxosrvr.  N and X can be made configurable. 5 minutes was assumed that it takes around a minute to start the mxosrvr and register etc.  30 minutes is the breathing time needed to get back the node to normal state externally.  If it doesn't , then you would say 6 cores every 30 minutes.  Choosing N is no brainier, it should be a little more than it takes mxosrvr to start and register etc. Default value of 6 for N seems reasonable.  Choosing X is bit hard.   If the mxosrvr dies quite often due to queries from the application, this time is dependent upon how much time the application can wait to get another connection. This would matter when the mxosrvr resource is tight otherwise the application can always find another server to connect.  Default value of 5 or 10 minutes may be fine.
BTW, I liked the way you have coded to implement some strategy
